title: Cloudflare 1.1.1.1 Incident on July 14, 2025
author: Unknown
summary: On July 14, 2025, Cloudflare's 1.1.1.1 Resolver service experienced a global outage for about an hour due to a misconfiguration of legacy systems used to maintain the infrastructure. This misconfiguration led to the inadvertent withdrawal of the 1.1.1.1 Resolver prefixes, causing DNS traffic to drop globally, triggering internal alerts, and necessitating a fix deployment to restore service. Cloudflare is implementing steps to mitigate similar incidents in the future by deprecating legacy systems and improving deployment methodologies for increased stability.

title: Six Years of Gemini
author: Unknown
summary: The article celebrates the sixth anniversary of Project Gemini's public announcement and reflects on the quiet year at geminiprotocol.net. The author acknowledges their own recent inactivity but highlights the ongoing contributions from the community in terms of patches, translations, and maintaining various services. Despite discontinuing the reporting of Geminispace size statistics, the author notes that most numbers have seen a slight increase.

title: Tilck: A Tiny Linux-Compatible Kernel
author: Unknown
summary: Tilck is an educational monolithic kernel that aims to be Linux-compatible at a binary level, running on i686 and RISCV64 architectures. It provides a playground for kernel development with a focus on real-world applications, supporting mainstream Linux programs like BusyBox and potentially filling the gap between Embedded Linux and real-time operating systems. Tilck emphasizes simplicity, reliability on real hardware, and a user-friendly development experience, making it accessible for both experienced engineers and beginners.

title: GPUHammer: Rowhammer attacks on GPU memories are practical
author: Unknown
summary: The article discusses GPUHammer, the first attack to demonstrate Rowhammer bit flips on GPU memories, specifically on an NVIDIA A6000 GPU with GDDR6 memory. The attack shows how bit flips induced by GPUs can tamper with data and degrade machine learning model accuracy, highlighting the need to assess the vulnerability of GPU memories to Rowhammer attacks and consider mitigation strategies such as enabling Error Correction Codes (ECC) despite potential performance impacts.

title: Show HN: Shoggoth Mini – A soft tentacle robot powered by GPT-4o and RL
author: Unknown
summary: The article discusses the importance of expressiveness in robotics for natural interactions, highlighting the development of Shoggoth Mini as an exploration of embodiment and intent communication. The design process involved creating a robotic tentacle system that could be controlled intuitively through a 2D mapping, incorporating elements of reinforcement learning and expressive behaviors to enhance the robot's perceived aliveness.

title: Reflections on OpenAI
author: Unknown
summary: The author reflects on their experience working at OpenAI, highlighting the rapid growth, bottoms-up culture, meritocracy, and intense focus on innovation and product development, particularly noting their involvement in the launch of the Codex coding agent. They emphasize the ambitious and secretive nature of OpenAI, the importance of distributed AI benefits, the organization's pace of work, and the significant impact of the Codex launch on their career.

title: NIST ion clock sets new record for most accurate clock
author: Unknown
summary: Researchers at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) have developed the most accurate clock in the world based on a trapped aluminum ion. This clock, with 19 decimal places of accuracy, is 41% more accurate and 2.6 times more stable than any previous record holder, paving the way for redefining the second and advancing physics and technology. The clock's design improvements involved addressing challenges in trap design, vacuum system, and laser stability, with the aluminum ion clock contributing to advancements in quantum physics and potentially exploring changes in fundamental constants of nature.

title: Where's Firefox going next?
author: Unknown
summary: The article on Mozilla Connect discusses Firefox users' feedback and suggestions for improving the browser, including requests for features like split view, improved Android interface flexibility, faster page loading, and resource consumption reduction. Users also express concerns about performance issues, browser memory usage, security improvements, and the need for better communication and messaging from the Firefox team. Overall, the community emphasizes the importance of optimizing performance, enhancing features, and refining the design of Firefox to meet user needs and expectations.

title: The FIPS 140-3 Go Cryptographic Module
author: Unknown
summary: Go has introduced native FIPS 140 support built into the standard library, making it easier and more secure for users to comply with FIPS 140 requirements. The FIPS 140-3 validated Go Cryptographic Module enhances security by integrating transparently into Go applications, offering compliance with approved algorithms and operating environments. This module surpasses the previous Go+BoringCrypto solution, providing a better compliance profile and access to a wider range of algorithms for FIPS 140-3 restricted applications.

title: When Root Meets Immutable: OpenBSD Chflags vs. Log Tampering
author: Unknown
summary: The article discusses the importance of ensuring the integrity of system logs for ISO 27001 compliance by using OpenBSD's immutable flags feature. It explains how to leverage OpenBSD's chflags command to protect log files from tampering and unauthorized access, ultimately creating a production-ready setup that automates the management of immutable log files during the boot process. This implementation provides a secure solution for maintaining the integrity of audit trails without the need for additional software or network dependencies.

title: Fully homomorphic encryption and the dawn of a private internet
author: Unknown
summary: The article discusses Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE), a technology that allows computations to be performed on encrypted data without needing to decrypt it first. While FHE is not yet practical due to high computational overhead, advancements are being made to improve its speed and efficiency, potentially revolutionizing privacy and security in cloud computing and other applications. The future implications suggest that as FHE becomes more accessible, it could lead to a shift towards encrypted internet computations, enhancing privacy by default.

title: NIH is cheaper than the wrong dependency
author: Unknown
summary: The article challenges the common belief that dependencies in coding are always beneficial, highlighting the costs and risks associated with using large, complex dependencies. It introduces TigerBeetle as an example of a project with a "zero dependencies" policy to avoid supply chain attacks and performance issues. The author emphasizes the importance of evaluating dependencies critically and choosing them wisely based on a Framework for Evaluating Dependencies that considers various criteria beyond just ergonomics.

title: Advertising Without Signal: The Rise of the Grifter Equilibrium
author: Unknown
summary: The article discusses how advertising on platforms like Amazon can create a "grifter equilibrium" where low-quality sellers can confuse consumers and operate alongside high-quality sellers. It explains how current advertising models, such as cost-per-acquisition (CPA) bidding, fail to effectively signal quality due to the ability of low-quality sellers to fund ads from initial sales. The article suggests potential remedies, such as return-adjusted CPA surcharges and relaunch detection, to deter entry by low-quality sellers and potentially restore a more effective signaling equilibrium.

title: Asynchrony is not concurrency
author: Unknown
summary: The article discusses the concept of asynchrony as distinct from concurrency and parallelism in programming, highlighting how asynchrony allows tasks to run out of order while still being correct. It emphasizes the importance of understanding the differences between these terms to improve software development practices, reduce code duplication, and enable the co-existence of synchronous and asynchronous code in the same codebase. The author also touches on the implications of these concepts in the context of Zig's async I/O redesign and invites readers to a live demonstration of the implementation on Twitch.

title: Linux and Secure Boot certificate expiration
author: Unknown
summary: The article discusses the upcoming expiration of a Microsoft key used for signing the shim first-stage UEFI bootloader for Secure Boot on Linux systems, which may impact system booting. The replacement key, available since 2023, may require hardware vendors to issue firmware updates, potentially leading to extra work for distributors and users to ensure system bootability with Secure Boot enabled. Additionally, the article mentions the potential challenges and solutions related to certificate expiration, firmware updates, and the role of tools like LVFS and fwupd in managing the transition to new keys for Secure Boot functionality.

title: Countries across the world see food price shocks from climate extremes
author: Unknown
summary: Research involving the Barcelona Supercomputing Center (BSC) shows that extreme weather events are causing food price shocks globally, affecting crops like potatoes, rice, fruit, and vegetables. These price spikes are leading to increased prices for consumers, particularly impacting low-income households who may have to resort to less nutritious, cheaper foods, which could worsen health outcomes. The study highlights the urgent need to address climate change to mitigate the effects of extreme weather on food production and prices.

title: More than you wanted to know about how Game Boy cartridges work
author: Unknown
summary: The article discusses the process of making a Game Boy cartridge from scratch, focusing on understanding how Game Boy cartridges work and detailing the components involved, such as the ROM chip, internal RAM, and cartridge RAM. It explains the role of the memory bank controller (MBC), which enables access to more ROM memory and on-cartridge RAM, and describes how ROM and RAM bank switching is achieved through the MBC5 chip. Additionally, it covers the use of battery-backed SRAM to store persistent data like saved games on Game Boy cartridges.

title: Algorithms for Modern Processor Architectures
author: Unknown

Lemire also mentions the impact of hard-to-predict branches on performance and provides insights into hash functions and processor learning capabilities for improved efficiency.

title: Android Earthquake Alerts: A global system for early warning
author: Unknown
summary: Google has developed the Android Earthquake Alerts system, utilizing the global network of Android smartphones to detect earthquakes and deliver early warnings to users in nearly 100 countries. The system has detected over 18,000 earthquakes, issued alerts for over 2000 significant events, and sent around 790 million alerts worldwide, significantly increasing the number of people with access to earthquake early warning systems. The system's continuous improvements in magnitude estimation and positive user feedback show its potential to provide valuable warnings and post-earthquake information to help create a safer world.

title: When Is WebAssembly Going to Get DOM Support?
author: Unknown
summary: The article discusses the readiness of WebAssembly (Wasm) for production usage in web applications, particularly in terms of its integration with web APIs like the DOM. It explains that while Wasm may not have direct access to the DOM, it is still suitable for various web-integrated uses through JavaScript APIs and compiler-generated glue code. The article also highlights the ongoing evolution of Wasm to reduce code size and improve performance, emphasizing the importance of prioritizing what makes programs work better rather than focusing solely on eliminating JavaScript.

title: Show HN: WTFfmpeg – Natural Language to FFmpeg Translator
author: Unknown
summary: wtffmpeg is a command-line tool that utilizes a local Large Language Model to convert plain English descriptions of video and audio tasks into executable ffmpeg commands. Users can interact with the tool to generate commands and make manual adjustments before execution, ensuring compatibility with ffmpeg syntax. The tool provides a convenient and potentially humorous way to work with ffmpeg commands but users are advised to review and validate generated commands before executing them to prevent any potential issues or data loss.

title: More than you wanted to know about how Game Boy cartridges work
author: Unknown
summary: The article discusses the process of creating a custom Game Boy cartridge using a RP2040 microcontroller and shares insights on how Game Boy cartridges work, including details on ROM, RAM, memory bank controllers, and bank switching. It explains the mechanisms behind ROM and RAM access, as well as the role of the MBC5 chip in enabling bank switching for ROMs and RAM on the cartridge, along with the importance of battery-backed SRAM for storing saved game data.
